Controversy Explanation: The university relocated a flag that was part of a nationally touring art exhibit from a flagpole atop a university building to inside the university art museum after the governor demanded its removal. The state governor said the flag was “disrespectful” and “absolutely unacceptable." Administrators claimed they were concerned about safety because of angry tweets and a call which a police investigation found to be “more harassing than threatening.” The governor continued to press the university to destroy the flag and even offered to have the Boy Scouts burn it. The university did not take the governor up on his offer.
Public Response:
Neutral (Disingenuous), Appeased Protesters. The Office of the Chancellor issued a statement: "Over the course of the day, the conversation around this display has generated public safety concerns for our campus community. While we want to foster difficult dialogue, we cannot allow that dialogue to put our people or property in harm’s way.

We have begun the process of relocating the exhibit to the Spencer Museum of Art, where we can continue the important conversation it has generated."

Controversy Explanation: The university president received numerous emails and letters asking it not to allow Farage to debate Vicente Fox. Farage spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university president responded to protesters in his opening remarks for the debate: “I am not so sure that we have been so successful in training you to be responsible citizens who know how to live rightly in a free society. . . .The role of a university is not to make ideas safe for students, it is to educate students.”

Controversy Explanation: Students claimed that a Turning Point USA event featuring Dave Rubin could "incite acts of racism, xenophobia, and transphobia." The event was moved from its original location because university police “had info of outside agitators” who planned to disrupt the event. At the event's new location students attempted to block people from entering the event and shouted over over Rubin during his speech. The event resumed and Rubin finished his remarks.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to disinvite Shapiro. A few days before the event, the university imposed a $5,500 security fee on the College Republicans, the hosting organization. The university waived the fee after being threatened with a lawsuit by the Alliance Defending Freedom and Shapiro spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). A university spokesperson said the decision was made to waive the fees "in light of the confusion over this issue and the difficult position the College Republicans would be in without additional funds."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Gender, Political Views, Race, Religion
Controversy Explanation: Students and student groups objected to Shapiro's appearance, claiming he is a purveyor of hate speech, a racist, and known to have made discriminatory comments against multiple minority communities. They protested, in part, by reserving seats in the event venue in order to prevent other students from attending. Shapiro spoke successfully.
Public Response: Neutral. the university public safety chief told reporters: “Our role is to make sure that all parties on campus may safely exercise their First Amendment rights in accordance with university policy.”

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Police, Race
Controversy Explanation: Outside groups protested Garcetti's speech, decrying his approach to city homelessness and police misconduct. Event organizers cut the speech short, fearing for Garcetti's safety.
Public Response: None

School: University of Southern Maine, Lewiston-Auburn College
Speaker/Performer/Title: Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape I
Controversy Explanation: The university ordered the painting, Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape I, and two other paintings removed from the campus art gallery after discovering that the artist is a convicted sex offender. All three paintings were removed.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An offical university statement said: "USM received a complaint from a member of the public. The complaint was not about the content of the art, but the artist. After careful review, USM decided to remove his works from this exhibit."

School: University of Southern Maine, Lewiston-Auburn College
Speaker/Performer/Title: Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape II
Controversy Explanation: The university ordered the painting, Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape II, and two other paintings removed from the campus art gallery after discovering that the artist is a convicted sex offender. All three paintings were removed.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An offical university statement said: "USM received a complaint from a member of the public. The complaint was not about the content of the art, but the artist. After careful review, USM decided to remove his works from this exhibit."

School: University of Southern Maine, Lewiston-Auburn College
Speaker/Performer/Title: Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape III
Controversy Explanation: The university ordered the painting, Industrial Maine: Our Other Landscape III, and two other paintings removed from the campus art gallery after discovering that the artist is a convicted sex offender. All three paintings were removed.
Public Response: Condemned Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An offical university statement said: "USM received a complaint from a member of the public. The complaint was not about the content of the art, but the artist. After careful review, USM decided to remove his works from this exhibit."

Controversy Topic(s): Criminal or Other Misconduct, Gender, Race
Controversy Explanation: Handler withdrew from speaking at commencement after facing criticism from students and alumni for his comments on gender and race and after being accused of sexual harassment. Anita Hill, who had been invited to the ceremony as an honorary doctorate recipient, replaced Handler as commencement speaker.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship. The university president stated: “Daniel Handler has chosen to withdraw as Wesleyan’s Commencement speaker this May. . . .We've agreed that the focus of the event should be on the Class of 2018, their families and the celebration of graduation."

Controversy Explanation: The theatre department canceled a production of the play, Beast Thing, because student actors felt uncomfortable with the material and worried that the violent content might have a harmful impact on audience members. Some faculty and students also complained that the production didn't include enough actors of color.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: College administrators informed George Cole, the artist and a student at the college, that he would not be allowed to enter Jesus First Bike (and The Hero) in the college's annual Student Art Exhibition becasue it depicted religious content and themes. Cole had previously won Best in Show twice, in 2009 and 2012. In both years members of the general community complained about Coles' offensive work and in 2012 called on the college to ban Cole from entering work into future exhibitions.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: College administrators informed George Cole, the artist and a student at the college, that he would not be allowed to enter The Hero (and Jesus First Bike) in the college's annual Student Art Exhibition becasue it depicted religious content and themes. Cole had previously won Best in Show twice, in 2009 and 2012. In both years members of the general community complained about Coles' offensive work and in 2012 called on the college to ban Cole from entering work into future exhibitions.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: McFarland, a Christian who believes tht life starts at conception, was invited to campus by Medical Students for Life, an on-campus student organization, to discuss when life actually begins at the medical school. Faculty and students objected to McFarland's invitation and the medical school's administrarion imposed substantial and excessive security fees. McFarland spoke sucessfully.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: Students, faculty, alumni, employees, and members of the Native American community, called on the university to remove 12 murals depicting Christopher Columbus' voyage across the Atlantic Ocean and discovery of the Americas in 1492 from the second-floor hall of the Main Buliding because they depict Native Americans and Blacks in subservient roles.  In early 2019 the university president announced that the murals would be covered "by woven material consistent with the décor of the space." Three years later the university uncovered the murals for a week for "instructional purposes."
Public Response: Neutral.  In a letter to the campus community the university president said: "Since the 1990s, a brochure has been provided that explains to viewers the context of the murals’ composition and some of the historical reality of the events depicted. However, because the second-floor hall of the Main Building is a busy throughway for visitors and members of the University community, it is not well suited for a thoughtful consideration of these paintings and the context of their composition. We will, therefore, create a permanent display for high-quality, high-resolution images of the murals in a campus setting to be determined that will be conducive to such an informed and careful consideration. The murals on the walls of the Main Building will themselves be covered by woven material consistent with the décor of the space, though it will be possible to display the murals on occasion. I will establish a committee to decide on the place to display the images of the murals and the appropriate communication around the display. We will begin soon the making of covers for the murals."

Source(s): Administrator(s), Alumni, Faculty, General Public, Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: The Hovey Murals, located in an old, locked dining hall that is no longer in use, depict a story about a group Native Americans who are tempted to drink and then enroll at Dartmouth by the college's founder. After Native American students complained aboutthem, college administrators formed the Hovey Murals Study Group --- consisting of students, faculty, staff, and alumni --- to decide whether the murals should be removed. The  HMSV recommended the college remove the murals and they were moved to a storage location off campus, they remain accessible to faculty who want to use them in their teaching or research.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters, Condemned Expression.  In a statement the university president said: "The derogatory images in the Hovey murals convey disturbing messages that are incompatible with Dartmouth’s mission and values. Moving them off-campus to Hood storage is the right thing to do."

Controversy Explanation: A student-led online petition called on the university to remove the murals from the Zimmerman Library on campus becasuse they are "inherently racist." The petition garnered over 1,000 signatures. On the recommendation of the university president and provost, the murals were covered.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: After students complained in an open forum a year earlier that they felt alienated and excluded by the murals, the university established a committee to make a recommendation to address the students' concerns. The committee recommended that the university remove the murals but preserve and archive them. The university removed the mural and established an online archive of them.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters.  In a statement a university senior vice president said: "Students have told us that they don’t want to receive awards in Alumnae Lounge because they feel excluded, and that’s important to hear. We want to attract a diversity of people to the university. But no less important, when they arrive, we want them to feel they belong here."

Controversy Explanation: About five minutes into his performance, Burress started projecting an email to the audience about the restrictions the university placed on his act, which included a ban n content involving rape, sexual assault, race and sexual orientation. He began mocking the university administrators and then made a joke about the Catholic Church's history of sexual abuse. Administrators then had Burress' mic cut off. Burress continued with his set without the mic before he was drowned out by music. He ultimately returned to the stage and made jokes about his mic getting cut off.
Public Response: Disingenuous.  A university spokesperson confirmed that Burress' mic was cut "because he violated the mutually agreed upon content restriction clause in his contract,"" and added: ""It is standard for the University to include a content restriction clause in entertainment contracts; Buress is the only entertainer to disregard the clause to the degree that his mic was cut. Buress eventually returned to the stage and completed his set."

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Boghossian, a philosophy professor at the university scheduled and moderated a discussion between James Damore (former Google engineer known for his controversial memo on gender differences in tech), Heather Heying (evolutionary biologist and critic of gender studies), and Helen Pluckrose (cultural critic and co-author of Cynical Theories), titled "We Need to Talk About Diversity." The event sought to discuss issues surrounding gender, diversity, and free speech. While the university ignored calls for the events cancellation and allowed it to proceed, it was disrupted by activists, who shut off the sound system and attempted to prevent the panelists from speaking. Video footage of the event shows demonstrators knocking over microphones and overturning sound equipment, forcing the discussion to continue without amplification.
Public Response: Honors.  The university's president stated that the university: "supports freedom of speech and academic inquiry for all its faculty and students" and that disruptions of campus events would not be tolerated.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Damore, a former Google engineer known for his controversial memo on gender differences in tech, participated on a panel discussion at the university with Heather Heying (evolutionary biologist and critic of gender studies) and Helen Pluckrose (cultural critic and co-author of Cynical Theories). The panel was titled "We Need to Talk About Diversity," and was moderated by Peter Boghossian (a philosophy professor at the university who organized the panel) and  sought to discuss issues surrounding gender, diversity, and free speech. While the university ignored calls for the events cancellation and allowed it to proceed, it was disrupted by activists, who shut off the sound system and attempted to prevent the panelists from speaking. Video footage of the event shows demonstrators knocking over microphones and overturning sound equipment, forcing the discussion to continue without amplification.
Public Response: Honors.  The university's president stated that the university: "supports freedom of speech and academic inquiry for all its faculty and students" and that disruptions of campus events would not be tolerated.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Pluckrose, a cultural critic and co-author of Cynical Theories, participated on a panel discussion at the university with Heather Heying (evolutionary biologist and critic of gender studies) and James Damore (a former Google engineer known for his controversial memo on gender differences in tech). The panel was titled "We Need to Talk About Diversity," and was moderated by Peter Boghossian (a philosophy professor at the university who organized the panel) and  sought to discuss issues surrounding gender, diversity, and free speech. While the university ignored calls for the events cancellation and allowed it to proceed, it was disrupted by activists, who shut off the sound system and attempted to prevent the panelists from speaking. Video footage of the event shows demonstrators knocking over microphones and overturning sound equipment, forcing the discussion to continue without amplification.
Public Response: Honors.  The university's president stated that the university: "supports freedom of speech and academic inquiry for all its faculty and students" and that disruptions of campus events would not be tolerated.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Heying, an evolutionary biologist and critic of gender studies, participated on a panel discussion at the university with  Helen Pluckrose (cultural critic and co-author of Cynical Theories) and James Damore (a former Google engineer known for his controversial memo on gender differences in tech). The panel was titled "We Need to Talk About Diversity," and was moderated by Peter Boghossian (a philosophy professor at the university who organized the panel) and  sought to discuss issues surrounding gender, diversity, and free speech. While the university ignored calls for the events cancellation and allowed it to proceed, it was disrupted by activists, who shut off the sound system and attempted to prevent the panelists from speaking. Video footage of the event shows demonstrators knocking over microphones and overturning sound equipment, forcing the discussion to continue without amplification.
Public Response: Honors.  The university's president stated that the university: "supports freedom of speech and academic inquiry for all its faculty and students" and that disruptions of campus events would not be tolerated.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Boghossian, a philosophy professor at the university scheduled and moderated a discussion with Carl Benjamin (AKA Sargon of Akkad), a British political commentator and former YouTuber who gained prominence for his critiques of feminism, social justice movements, and political correctness. Boghossian and Benjamin's discussion focused on the topic of free speech and Bias Response Teams. During the discussion, a disruptor pulled a fire alarm in an apparent attempt to shut down the event. This forced an evacuation but ultimately backfired, as attendees continued the conversation outside.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Benjamin (AKA Sargon of Akkad), a British political commentator and former YouTuber who gained prominence for his critiques of feminism, social justice movements, and political correctness was invited to campus by Peter Boghossian, a philosophy professor at the university, for a discussion. about free speech and Bias Response Teams. During the discussion, a disruptor pulled a fire alarm in an apparent attempt to shut down the event. This forced an evacuation but ultimately backfired, as attendees continued the conversation outside.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Topic(s): Civil Liberties, Gender, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Folsom, a historian and senior fellow at the Foundation for Economic Education, was invited by the college's chapter of Young Americans for Freedom to speak on economic policy. His scheduled lecture sparked criticism from students and faculty who objected to his perspectives on history and economics, particularly his critiques of government intervention and welfare programs. Opponents also raised concerns about his affiliation with conservative organizations. Amid the controversy, some faculty members and students called for the event’s cancellation. However, the college allowed the lecture to proceed as planned and Folsom spoke successfully on campus.
Public Response: None.

Controversy Explanation: Students, a professor, and alumni created a display that included tweets, speeches, and recordings of Donald Trump; a Bob Dylan song; audio and video from the Nazi propaganda film, The Triumph of the Will; and miniature phallic figures intended to look like Trump. After a student anonymously filed a complaint about the display, and other students sent emails supporting the installation, the administration demanded that the creators of the display deinstall it.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: Administrators withdrew an invitation to Murray to speak on campus, citing an inability to provide adequate security should violent protests erupt. No evidence of any threat materialized, but disruptive protests had erupted earlier that year at other colleges where Murray had spoken (Middlebury, six months earlier). At other colleges where Murray had spoken (Harvard, a week earlier), only peaceful demonstrations occurred.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). Articles reported "In fact, while there was no explicit threat of a protest, recent violence both at Murray’s talks and around the country led to the event’s cancellation, Executive Director of Communication Michael Guilfoyle told The Telegram."

Controversy Explanation: Osler, a former Baylor Law School professor, was disinvited by the university chaplain from holding his talk at the chapel because of his criticism of the Baptist church and the university regarding issues of sexual assault and gay marriage.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Topic(s): Class or Policy Issues, Political Views
Controversy Explanation: Students petitioned the university to disinvite DeVos from delivering a commencement speech because of DeVos's comments on school choice, the university's policies on student borrowers, and her connection with the Trump administration. DeVos was booed and heckled throughout her speech, but finished her remarks.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The president of the university responded to hecklers as follows: “If this behavior continues, your degrees will be mailed to you. . . . Choose which way you want to go.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Casey Jr. because of Casey Jr.'s views on contraception and abortion and his support for gay marriage. Casey Jr. spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: Students, and at least one alumna, protested Buyer Beware, claiming the play was racist. Protests included an organized phone, email, and social media campaign to pressure administrators and faculty members to cancel the play. Faculty decided, instead, to postpone production of the play until the following semester so they could arrange to provide more educational context, including a course on provocative works. The playwright, Michael Weller, decided to produce the play off-campus.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. After receiving a draft script of “Buyer Beware” in early July, theater faculty members considered the challenging issues it raised. They felt that more time was needed to produce the play appropriately, and that its performance on campus should go hand-in-hand with robust educational programming. In early September, Mr. Weller and faculty discussed possible dates in February for the production of the play. Mr. Weller was also informed about the creative arts faculty's decision to design a team-taught course around the play and other provocative works of art in the spring semester, which would accompany the production of the play.

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Gender, Immigration, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty petitioned the university to keep Yiannopoulos from speaking because they perceived his rhetoric as hateful toward minority groups. Protests occurred outside the event and multiple people were arrested, but Yiannopoulos spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university communications department issued a statement, which included the following: "Mr. Yiannopoulos is a controversial figure, but the University administration does not play a role in determining which speakers student groups may invite to campus. Throughout our 60-year history, our institution has been — and must always be — a marketplace of ideas in which diverse perspectives from all sides of issues are explored in a safe environment that upholds the right to freedom of expression, which is fundamental to our educational mission and to American democracy."

Controversy Explanation: The Theological College, which invited Martin, uninvited him because of his pro-LGBT opinions. The university president spoke out against the decision and said it didn't reflect university policy.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university president said: “Universities and their related entities should be places for the free, civil exchange of ideas. Our culture is increasingly hostile to this idea. It is problematic that individuals and groups within our Church demonstrate this same inability to make distinctions and to exercise charity.”

School: City University of New York, School of Law
Controversy Explanation: Students demanded that the university cancel the event, claiming that Bharara unfairly wielded the law to the detriment of racial minorities in his time as U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York. Bharara spoke successfully.
Public Response: None

School: City University of New York, City College, CUNY Graduate School of Public Health & Health Policy
Source(s): Activist(s), General Public, Politician(s), Public Figure(s), Student(s)
Controversy Explanation: Students started an online petition demanding that Sarsour's invitation to speak at commencement be rescinded. Other students, activist groups, and a New York state assemblyman objected to the university's invitation of Sarsour because of Sarsour's views on Israel and demanded that the state's governor and city's mayor revoke Sarsour's invitation. Sarsour spoke successfully.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The CUNY chancellor issued a statement that read: "The commencement speakers are selected at the college level … Taking action because critics object to the content of speech would conflict with the First Amendment and the principles of academic freedom."

Controversy Explanation: Students from Black Lives Matter objected to Mac Donald's views on policing and blocked entry to the venue. Mac Donald snuck in but few students were able to enter. The speech was livestreamed from a mostly empty hall and posted online for further viewing. The college suspended five students who were part of the barricade.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The college president put in an official statement: "[T]he breach of our freedoms to listen to views that challenge us and to engage in dialogue about matters of controversy is a serious, ongoing concern we must address effectively. Accordingly, we will be developing new strategies for how best to protect open, safe access to our events."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the college to rescind its invitation of Vullo to deliver a commencement speech because of Vullo's efforts to require insurance companies to provide free coverage for contraceptives and "medically necessary" abortions. Vullo spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: Students objected to Guthrie Gastañaga speaking because they were upset that the ACLU defends the free speech rights of white supremacists. As Guthrie Gastañaga began to speak, Black Lives Matter protesters took over the stage and refused to let the event proceed. After the event, they shouted Guthrie Gastañaga down as she attempted to speak individually with students who had questions.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The college's president published a prepared statement after the event: "Silencing certain voices in order to advance the cause of others is not acceptable in our community. This stifles debate and prevents those who've come to hear a speaker, our students in particular, from asking questions, often  hard questions, and from engaging in debate where the strength of ideas, not the power of shouting, is the currency. William & Mary must be a campus that welcomes difficult conversations, honest debate and civil dialogue."

Controversy Explanation: Black Lives Matter and the Southern Poverty Law Center objected to Columbia College Republicans' invitation of Robinson to campus, claiming his views are "racist and harmful." Robinson was unable to speak over protesters who continuously disrupted the event.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. An article reported "In an email to the Columbia community Tuesday afternoon, Executive Vice President for University Life Suzanne Goldberg denounced white supremacism but emphasized the University’s commitment to allow student groups to invite speakers that express hateful views."

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Gender, Political Views, Race, Religion, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: The student government rescinded funding for an event featuring Shapiro after the college had granted it, citing Shapiro's alleged "hate speech" toward marginalized communities.
Public Response: None

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Farmer to deliver a commencement speech because Farmer's healthcare charity endorses and promotes contraception and runs a condom education program. Farmer spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Controversy Explanation: The DePaul College Republicans first proposed inviting McInnes to speak in the fall. After the student organization agreed to the administration's conditions, the university still disinvited McInnes the following spring. The administration claimed it had to cancel McInnes' speech because McInnes encouraged violence.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The university president sent an email to students that stated: “The encouragement of violence . . .has no place here. This is not about the content of McInnes’ speech, but about his public endorsement of violence and the establishment of a military division of his own group, the Proud Boys.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society urged the university to rescind its invitation of Brown to deliver a commencement speech because of Brown's support for gay marriage and LGBTQ rights. Brown spoke successfully.
Public Response: Unknown

Speaker/Performer/Title: Palliative Art: Using the Arts to Improve Care at the End of Life
Controversy Explanation: TFP Student Action, an off-campus group, started a petition opposing the art exhibit Palliative Art: Using the Arts to Improve Care at the End of Life because a pro-assisted suicide group was co-hosting the event. The petition included a pre-drafted letter addressed to the university president and garnered more than 11,500 signatures. The event proceeded as planned.
Public Response: None

Controversy Topic(s): Abortion, Criminal or Other Misconduct, Political Views, Sexuality
Controversy Explanation: TFP Student Action, an off-campus organization, started an online petition calling on the university to cancel Davis' appearance because she is a Marxist, communist activist who promotes abortion and same-sex marriage. Davis spoke successfully.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president wrote: "While these things may be true of Dr. Davis [the noncontroversial things mentioned in the speaking announcement], we find it inappropriate to hide the many other parts of her life that may be found less popular."

Controversy Explanation: Students and alumni petitioned the college to disinvite then-Vice President Pence from speaking at commencement because, in their view, the selection of Pence did not accurately reflect the school's Christian values and inviting him to speak amounted to a tacit endorsement of the Trump administration. Both student and nonstudent activists organized a protest and some faculty said they would boycott commencement. Pence spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university president released a statement which included: "We are proud to welcome the Vice President and we are thankful that our graduates will have the opportunity to bear witness to his deep and abiding faith, quiet humility, and compelling leadership in challenging times. . . . This will be a lifetime memory for the class of 2017."

Controversy Explanation: Administrators canceled Okafor's speech two hours before it was scheduled to begin after students and faculty protested Okafor's support for the Second Amendment.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The university issued a statement that stated: "We did not cancel the speech because of the speaker, the subject of the speech, or the content. Hampshire College values academic freedom and the careful examination of ideas, including when those ideas may be controversial. We canceled the event when we realized that the student application . . . lacked the necessary details we require in advance of any event, particularly one that might draw large audiences and intense debate, so we can allot the appropriate resources to staff and support the event. We will reach out to Antonia Okafor -- Black, Armed, and Conservative and to the student organizers with an offer to discuss this process and consider options for rescheduling her visit to campus."

Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty petitioned the university to disinvite Murray due to Murray's views on race and intelligence. Protesters outside the building were so loud they could be heard inside, but Murray finished his talk.
Public Response:
Honor Roll, High Honors
Neutral. The university provost issued a statement that ended with: "I sympathize deeply with the instinct to protect our community members from the felt insult accompanying the presence of someone whose work has become a symbol, fairly or not, of eugenics. But I cannot agree that we are a stronger community, or that we respect our students' and colleagues' agency and intellectual development, by weakening the values of free speech and free inquiry that define what it means to be a university."

Controversy Explanation: Theatre students opposed the performance of the play, The Good Person of Szechwan, because of its portrayal of Asians — Asian women, in particular — and because the play's setting was being changed to Europe by faculty directing the performance because there were not enough people of color on campus to fill East Asian roles. The theater department decided not to proceed with the performance.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship, Appeased Protesters. The college said that it's "proud of the open dialogue between our students and faculty, which addressed important issues and concerns that frame our faculty's teaching. . . . [W]e welcome disagreement, dialogue and debate among our community members. It is essential to our mission as a liberal arts college.”
